div.sent: Prince Siddhartha or Gautama Buddha was born at Kapilavastu, a small kingdom situated at the foot of the Himalayas.
His father was the king of the Sakya clan.
He attained supreme Enlightenment and became the Buddha at the age of 35 in 588 B.C.
He passed away into Parinibbana at Kusinara in 543 B. C. The truth that He discovered through Enlightenment were the Four Noble Truths.
The Noble Eight-fold path is a part and parcel of this truth.
Even no other great men could find out this truth before He discovered it.
He attained the supreme knowledge by Himself and proclaimed the same to all living beings for their benefit.
Thus He became the Samma Sambuddha, the most Perfected One.
The Buddha introduced very simple rules for those who, being convinced by His teachings and messages wanted to embrace the new religion.
In it lies primarily, the simple and easy principle of socialism.
The Buddha Himself was a great humanist.
The social reformation at that time was only possible through democratic revolutions.
He played a significant role for social reformations to establish equality among the people living in the society.
In this respect, He extensively attacked the Brahmins who claimed superiority, over others by birth.
A nice example is found in the Madhura Sutra included in the Majjhima Nikaya of the Tripitaka.
Here is the summary : Once the Bhikkhu Kaccayana was staying at Brindabana very close to Mathura.
By this time Avantiputra, the king of Mathura went to him and asked, Venerable kaccayana, the Brahmins are superior by castes while others are inferiors.
The Brahmins can free themselves from worldly bondage but not the others.
The Brahmins have come out of the mouth of the Brahma (the creator).
What is your idea about this?
Kaccayana replied, Your excellency, this is nothing but as sound or baseless speech.
Yes, Venerable Kaccayana, the people of these four castes must come forward to serve him.
The king agreed that in that case the people of the four castes would come to serve him must.
Then Venerable Kaccayana said, Does it not prove that all men are equal?
If so, said the king, all men of the four castes are equal.
So have I told you that, said Kaccayana, the superiority of the Brahmins is mere a sound or baseless speech.
Venerable Kaccayana again said, If anybody of the four castes commits sin by killing living being must suffer in return.
After a long discussions on various aspect the king Avantiputra agreed that all men of the four castes are equal.
Thus in the eyes of the Buddha there was no difference among the people of the four castes.
The Buddha strongly protested the idea of the Brahmins who claimed their superiority merely on the basis of birth and refuted it with strong reasonability.
To the Buddha the power of character makes a man virtuous or a beast.
The real identity of a man is revealed by his character and not by his birth.
There are so many nice stories relating to the Buddha with the Brahmins.
The Buddha, throughout his life, struggled to establish the equal rights of the people hailing form Brahmins and non-Brahmins.
Here is another story in this respect: Once the Buddha appeared before a Brahmin with his alms-bowl.
The Brahmin was a cultivator.
He felt annoyed and advised the, Buddha to earn livelihood by cultivation like him.
In a very mild tone the Buddha replied that he was also a cultivator.
But instead of land He cultivates human-minds for eternal peace.
The Brahmin was highly pleased and offered Him alms with utmost devotion.
During the Buddha's period the lower caste of the society like Sudras possessed no religious right to observe.
He was the Buddha who for the first time conferred this right to them.
He tried to unite all the people of the high or low caste, the Brahmin or non-Brahmin, even rich or poor.
He gave equal right to all the people in His doctrine.
He knew that it would grow a very strong social bondage among the people.
Because it was evident that the people of the lower caste always feared the higher ones.
Consequently the people of the higher caste hated the lower ones.
The Buddha inspired the people of all the castes to uproot these difference.
In His Sangha there was no difference at all among the disciples.
The Buddha gave shelter to many people of lower caste in His Sangha.
Once He was staying at the Anupriya Mango grove.
By this time Anuruddha along with his five Kshatriya friends approached Him for ordination.
Upali, the son of a barber was also with them.
The Buddha ordained Upali at first.
It evidently made him senior to others who had to pay tribute to him.
So they felt no racial sentiment while paying tribute to barber Upali.
Sunita was a sweaper.
Once the Buddha went out for alms along with his disciples.
He entered the road while Sunita was cleaning it.
He atone kept the carriage of dirt's and himself very close to the wall.
But the Buddha was still advancing towards him.
Such was the case that Sunita could rescue himself keeping invisible to the Buddha.
Then the Buddha said to him, Sunita, what is the benefit to live such a suffering life?
Will you enter the order of the Sangha?
Being attracted by the sweet voice of the Buddha he said, Oh Lord!
Is there any provision for a worthless man like me, to enter the Sangha then why should l not avail the opportunity?
Please permit me to enter the Sangha.
The Buddha took him to the monastery and ordained him as a Bhikkhu (monk).
He attained Arahanthood very soon by dint of his arduous practice in meditation.
Thera Kulla was a cultivator.
Thera Yosoja and Thera Hiranyaka were the sons of a gardener and a thief respectively.
Again Channa or Chandaka was a son of a maid servant and Thera Vimala was the son of the prostitute Amrapali.
Many others of such ordinary families were disciples of the Buddha who became eminent by their virtuous performances.
The women of ancient India had no right to observe the religious rites.
The Buddha gave the women entrance into the Bhikkhuni Sangha denying their social status.
Even the prostitutes, the women left by their husbands and the poor widows were given opportunity to enter into the Sangha.
Avoiding the social system of that time He accorded honour to those hated and destitute women folks giving shelter in his doctrine (Dhamma).
Amrapali was a prostitute of Vaisali.
So she possessed no social dignity.
Once she went to Kotigram to meet the Buddha.
She with great honour invited the Buddha to go to her house for having meals there.
The Buddha gladly accepted the invitation.
As she returned, the Licchavis came to know the fact.
The Licchavis were the Kshatriyas by caste.
They said to her,Oh Amrapali, we shall offer you one lac coins if you withdraw the invitation in our favour.
In reply she said, I shall not give up my right at the cost of whole Vaisali kingdom.
Then the Licchavi princes went to the Buddha and requested Him to refuse the invitation of Amrapali and to accept theirs in consequence.
The Buddha denied their request as Amrapali invited Him first.
Infact the Buddha paid more importance to Amrapali than the Licchavi princes.
He did not pay emphasis to the Licchavis, though they were born of royal families.
In the Buddha's doctrine both men and women were equally treated.
This may be truly realized from a conversation between Bhikkhuni Soma and the Mara, the god of evil.
Once Bhikkhuni Soma was in meditation in the Andhavana near Sravasti.
In reply Soma said, Whoever can concentrate his/her mind and well aware of right path of Dhamma, why should it be impossible to attain Nibbana?
Those who say that they are man or woman or anything else, let Mara go to those proud people to disturb them.
Bhikkhuni Soma has recognised me as Mara, thinking so, he left the place with a mournful heart.
By this conversation it is clear that the place of the women was so significant in the Sangha.
In this way the Buddha established equal rights between man and woman in His doctrine.
Religious and scriptural practices among the lower class people were held high in Buddhism which are evident from many examples in the Therigatha.
A destitute woman known as Sumangal's mother started meditation to get rid of earthly sufferings.
This led her to attain Arahanthood.
Vimala, the daughter of a prostitute of Vaisali found Moggallayana while begging alms and fell in love with him.
With the advice of Moggallayana she became Bhikkhuni (Nun) and achieved the supreme wisdom of Nibbana.
On the other hand the queens, the princesses and the daughters of the Setthis were allowed to enter into the Bhikkhuni Sangha.
In ancient Buddhism there was no difference between men and women in practising religious and scriptural rites and meditation.
There was even no domination in the religious rights over the womenfolk.
Many of the women were learned enough in the Dhamma and its philosophy.
They could debate on the religious subjects proving their knowledge as identical as the Bhikkhus.
The spirit of debate is found in the biographies of Theri Bhadra and Kundalkeshi.
On request of Ananda the Buddha set up the Bhikkhuni Sangha.
At that time there were nuns in Jainism too.
So He set up the Bhikkhuni Sangha not only on Ananda's request but to meet the social need of the time also.
He for the first time gave permission to Gautami for ordination as Bhikkhuni.
It means that the women can exercise their rights in the society as well as in Dhamma and Sangha.
In fact we can say that the Buddha introduced equal rights for men and women in preaching His religion as well.
The Buddha never kept anything secret of His doctrine.
In reply Ananda said, My lord, we have no controversy over your doctrine.
Because he knew that nothing is everlasting on earth rather changeable or transitory.
He asked His disciples to bring ammendment to rules of the Dhamma and the Sangha that He preached throughout His life.
For example, He gave invitation to all into his doctrine bringing them before Him causing too many disadvantages.
To remove the inconveniences the Buddha permitted the Sangha to initiate the willing persons anywhere at any time.
Collection of cloths from the laities was not permissible.
There after, he approved Kathinacivara dana, i.e. robe offering ceremony for the lay devotees to serve the purpose.
Likewise the Bhikkhus could have their meals at night.
But later on He prohibitted the system of taking meals after 12 A.M.
He further prohibitted the Bhikkhus to wear the shoes made of skins of the cows, the buffaloes and the deer.
He also introduced the custom of partaking the five, eight and ten Precepts.
Thus He reformed His doctrine during His life time.
More than once, the rules of performance were reformed in the Councils held later on.
In this way the Dhamma and the Vinaya were revised.
Soon after His Parinibbana, little reformation in the Dhamma Vinaya had been continued.
The Buddha introduced more rules to equalize the people of high and low castes living in the society.
He thus declared seven important disciplinary rules for the Vajjis.
They were independent living in a democratic state.
They earnestly followed the rules by dint of which they could protect their freedom unitedly and powerfully for many years.
Vaisali was the capital of the Vajjis.
He introduced more seven rules for the Bhikkhus like the Vajjis.
The introduction of those rules indicates the democratic views of the Buddha.
Arahanthood is attainable to all.
This message of the.
Buddha symbolizes the equality in men and women.
He erased the caste system of the society.
Because the limbs of the whole human body are same bearing no separate identity among the people by caste.
Man is known by his activities.
He advised all to abstain from sacrificial rites.
Because the poor farmers had to arrange for the sacrificial animals for the kings.
The kings forcefully collected the animals causing a great loss and suffering to the poor farmers.
He rather advised to sacrifice the animality of the human mind instead of sacrificing the animals.
The Buddha thought of such a human society to be formed by amity without weapons.
So he advised to conquer the evils with good deeds and enmity with friendship.
The democracy set by the Buddha for the welfare of all human beings was unprecedented in the history.
The Buddha was compassionate to all living beings.
He proclaimed His doctrine not for man only but for the happiness of all living beings.
To the Buddhist, the life of both friend and foe is always valuable.
The Buddha said, Violence is not restrained by violence, but it may only be restrained by amity.
Thus he thought of all living beings similarly.
The Buddha always tried his best to improve the mentality and character of human beings.
His aim was to establish peace not for man only, but for all living beings.
He neither converted the people of other faiths by force nor brought them for trial or prosecution.
Oppression, harassment even persecutions for non- Buddhists are not found in the teachings of the Buddha.
There is no instance of the destruction of the holy places of the people other than Buddhists.
To show respect and tolerance to the people of other faiths are the basic teachings of Buddhism.
The Buddha preached His doctrine in Pali, the most comprehensive language of the common people.
The great humanist like the Buddha is hardly found in the present even in the past ages.
He treated all living beings equally.
